Now gentle blastes, forerunners of the day,</br>Had summond hatefull Darknes packe away:</br>And Horror, Coachman unto oughly night,</br>Made his blacke Steeds poast with all speed he might,</br>From foorth our Hemisphere, not daring bide</br>To looke upon Auroras gorgious pride.</br>And now from new spows'd wife, the fierie Sunne</br>Was risen, and from Ocean seas begunne,</br>To drive his golden Chariot, that he might</br>To all the world declare his glorious light.</br>When Thamesis, the fairest Queene on earth,</br>To solemnise her annuall day of birth,</br>Appareled in Robe of purest white,</br>All thicke of golden shimiring Spangles dight;</br>Which gainst the Sunne reflecting beames did cast,</br>As do the Starres, that in the heavens are plast.</br>Her haire bound up in knots like golden Wier,</br>And crownd with Garlands of sweete smelling Brier;</br>Unto a Meddow by, his flowing streames</br>Did goe:  where she from heat of Phoebus beames,</br>Under the coole shade of the spreading Trees,</br>Did meane to sport and sing sweete virolees.</br>With her faire Nimphes, each having in her hand,</br>To fill with precious flowers a little maund.

It was about the selfe same time of yeare,</br>When from the midst of heaven the Sunne doth beare</br>His scorching heate, and makes it swiftly role,</br>Unto the Starres of the Antartique Pole.</br>Then when Pomona lades her slender bowes,</br>To serve Autumnus her diseased spowse.</br>Autumnus who in presse with naked feete,</br>From sweete ripe Grapes, make pleasant Wines to fleete.

In Ivorie hand faire Thames a Maund did hold,</br>Most rarely painted, and adorned with golde,</br>Which precious Jewell great Ocean did</br>To Doris give, what time he did her wed:</br>Which precious rich Maund lovely Doris after,</br>Did give to Thames her derling and her daughter.

Upon that Maund were many Histories</br>Depicted in such rare and curious wise,</br>That seemd as Art with Nature strove t' excell</br>In the rare workmanshyp, for none could tell,</br>Save Vulcane, who some sayd, did make the same,</br>How like to it, an other Maund to frame.

There might y' have seene a very stately Bed,</br>Made like a Boat; which certaine Tritons did</br>With their strong scalie backes uphold and stay,</br>All armde with Oares, all coullard like the Seat</br>Bout whom, faire Sea-Nimphs sported chearfully,</br>Delighted with the Tritons company:</br>Where, on the poop, stood Neptune; who did hold</br>In his right hand his Trident tinde with gold.</br>And under his left arme a winding Shell,</br>Like those from whence (as ancient Poets tell)</br>The heades of Tiber and of Nilus ran,</br>Or ere their floodes unto the salt Sea came.

Joves braine-bred-daughter at the prow was placed,</br>Armed as then when she from heaven chaced</br>The hundred handed Titan to his grave,</br>Upon the Fish that did Orson save.</br>The Testerne like a Tile, all covered</br>With purple Velvet richly imbrodered,</br>With orient round Pearle was supported by;</br>Certaine faire Sea-Nimphes on whose head did lie,</br>The Arched Ribbes in very stately order,</br>As on so many columnes on a border</br>Bout which was painted the imagerie</br>Of many Sea-gods, very curiously;</br>With Curtaines suitable thereto:  whereon</br>The Romaine Lucrece livelesse, pale, and wan,</br>Lay all besmeared in her owne goare blood,</br>Which with a Poyniard her owne hand had shod,</br>As sacrifice unto her chastitie;</br>Which was bereav'd by Tarquine spightfully.</br>And there by cunning Woorkman curiously,</br>Was made a Land-shaft, in which one might see,</br>Steepe craggie Rockes, high Mountaines, shady Woodes,</br>Greene pleasing Fieldes, and crooked winding Floodes;</br>Where, in the middle of a pleasant Lawne,</br>There was a stately Fountaine sweetly drawne;</br>Whose water from a Harpies breast did fall,</br>Of Brasse, into a Cesterne paved all</br>With polisht Marble, and with Porphire stone;</br>In which the Painter had his cunning showne,</br>In neately laying of his cullours, that</br>It seemd a true Fount, and no counterfect:</br>In which was chast Diana with her Nimphes,</br>All naked, bathing of their tender limbes;</br>On whom Acteon in the changed shape</br>Of fearefull Deare, full greedily did gape,</br>Turned thereto because he should not tell,</br>Had seene Diana naked in a Well:</br>By whom were made his wearie Hound that lapped</br>The water which from foorth the Fountaine dripped;</br>Whom fearing, he did seeke to flie:  for as</br>His body, so his minde transformed was;</br>And on the hanger of a Hill hard by,</br>The Dogges pinching his hantches you might see;</br>A rewfull sight, yet could not be amended,</br>Since he Dianas grace had so offended.</br>And bout the Verges seemely to behold,</br>Trailes of Morisco workes were wrought in gold.

Thus lovely Isis with his comely traine</br>Of beauteous Nimphes, into the Meddow came;</br>Where, on one side a shady Forrest grew;</br>To Which Aurora oft her selfe withdrew,</br>To heare her Loves complaint, and where the Moone,</br>Oft stayde to looke upon the Latmian Lowne:</br>In which did grow the tough and hardie Ashe,</br>The builder Oke; Holme fit for Carters lash,</br>Chast lovely Daphne closed under rinde,</br>Incestuous Mirh, that weepeth still of kind:</br>Then peaceful Olive, and the holsome Pine;</br>The sayling Firre, and eke the drunken Vine:</br>Upon whose boughes, pearcht the lascivious Sparrow,</br>The temperate Turtle, and the wight wingd Swallow,</br>Who flying singes, and singing studieth where,</br>With more art then with cost, her nest to reare:</br>The which, as patterne may be looked on</br>By rarest Archytect and cunningst man.</br>The little Owsle, and the mounting Larke;</br>The prettie Qualie, and charitable Storke,</br>Whose kindnesse to olde Parents children learne;</br>For oft to aged Parents you are more sterne.</br>High flying Cranes, by whose orderly flight,</br>Mars first was taught in rancked squadrons fight.</br>And peacoks, which against the Sunne do reare</br>Their painted tayles with Argus eyes made faire.</br>With little Nightingales, who divers fly</br>With changed notes do make sweet melodie,</br>Feigning sometime a base, sometime a trebble,</br>Often a meane, then sweetely foorth do warble</br>A descant, which the mindes of standers by,</br>Doth ravish, hearing such sweet harmonie.

On th' other side, a secret Cave was seene,</br>Which for his fitnesse, often times hath beene</br>A refuge for those Nimphes, the which would shunne,</br>The scortching heate of Midday of the Sunne:</br>The entrance deckt with Mosse, pleasing the sight,</br>And alway fresh and greene for more delight,</br>To land-ward did there rise a Hill so high,</br>That wel-nie it did face the azurd skie:</br>From foote of which, did runne a purling Brooke</br>Through the Meade, with many a widning crooke:</br>Whose slyding streames the heavens calme seemd blew,</br>Whence store of pleasure to the eye-sight grew;</br>Yet clearer then was Aganippe Fount,</br>Or Acidalia, where the Charicts wount</br>To bath their Ivorie breastes and golden haire,</br>Ere they make readie Citherea's care.</br>About whose bankes did grow small tangled Trees,</br>Which made it seeme a heaven to gasers eyes:</br>Whose boughes the needie Wood-man neare had cut,</br>Nor hungrie Beaste the tender shootes had brut.</br>And in the middle of that Meddow grew</br>A stately Beech, which his large armes foorth threw</br>To shadow them that under her should sport,</br>To which with Lea, Isis did resort</br>With Lea; on whose bankes Ardea was turned</br>Into a Bitterne, cause she Glaucus scorned.</br>Whilst Colne, and Kenet, with the faire Chrew went</br>To gather flowers of most pleasing sent;</br>For there were Roses with Virmilion died,</br>Coole Dasies, and white Lillies; Summers pride:</br>The Marigold, that doth affect the Sunne,</br>Hiding her beautie when his light is gonne:</br>The Bee alluring Thime, the sweete Costmarie,</br>Gray Lavender, and strong senting Rosemarie,</br>And what else might be pleasing to the view,</br>Within this faire and princely Meddow grew:</br>But that which garnisht most this Paradise,</br>Were Isis lovely looke, and sparkling eyes.</br>For marke how brighter Cinthia doth appeare</br>Above the Starres within her motive Spheere:</br>So much more fairer did this lovely Dame</br>Exceede those comely Nimphes, that which here came.

Not shee, whom Venus gave for the rich Ball,</br>The cause of tenne yeares warre, and Troyes fall:</br>Nor that faire Dame whom Jove in shape of Swan,</br>Whylome did court, when he her love first wan:</br>Nor yet Europa, whose love made him take</br>A proude Bulles shape (tho then when he did make)</br>To looke like a faire untamed Heyfer:</br>Had he turnd to a Bull, it had been better;</br>For beautie might in any poynt compare</br>To Isis, tho they were exceeding faire.

You learned Muses, race of mighty Jove,</br>That often sport within a sacred Grove,</br>In pleasant Tempe, and do dayly drinke,</br>Of those cleare waves that flow from Pinples brinke.</br>O you that guide their enterprises right,</br>Who take in hand to grave with rarest flight,</br>Upon the Alter of Muemosine,</br>Within the Temple of Immortalitie,</br>Sweete pleasing beautie, which else subject were,</br>In shade of lasting silence still to ere,</br>Guide me, that with your helpe I may begin</br>To frame Thams beautie; whose like neare hath bin:</br>And graunt these Rithmes, which slenderly are done,</br>May shew hereafter when as I am gone.</br>She was the fairst and most accomplisht Dame,</br>Excelling 'all whom Nature ere did frame.

Her heavenly Head the miracle of Nature,</br>Surpassing farre the fairest earthly creature:</br>With yellow Tramels all of beaten gold,</br>Which gasers thoughts in curled knots did hold;</br>Seemd overspred with flowers fresh and gay,</br>the mirtle Forests where the loves do play.</br>Like to a Table was her Front to see,</br>Of whitest Marble, seate of Majestie:</br>Well polished, as on a summers daie,</br>Withouten waves united seemes the Sea:</br>Where Cupid had an Alter built to offer,</br>Their hartes that did refuse his lawes to suffer.</br>Her Eye-lids blacke, of Heben arches made,</br>Were like the bow that Psiches husband had;</br>In which so liberall was Nature to her,</br>That every one suspected (that did view her)</br>She onely 'made faire Isis to deceave them:</br>And both of sight and judgement to bereave them.

Of different force were her two sparckling eyes.</br>Disdaine in th' one, grace in the other lyes:</br>Two eyes?  O no, rather two heavenly Starres;</br>Th' one proffering Peace, the other threatning Warres:</br>In which Mars bastard Boy, his lodging tooke</br>Thence wounding them which at those starres did looke.</br>Her Nose did seeme (being somewhat highly raysed)</br>A little HIll betweene two Vallies placed.</br>Here round and tender Eare, white polished:</br>With Rubies hung her Cheekes embellished:</br>Cheekes which with lively Cynab're ore spred,</br>Seemd like the Morning, new risse from her bed.</br>Not all those Flowers sprung from Princes gore,</br>Not Amaranthus loves Flower made of Yore,</br>Like colour had to hers, which did amaze</br>Those carelesse eyes, that on her cheekes did gaze.</br>Full was her Mouth of thousand Odours sweete,</br>Where there in single ranckes did seemely meete</br>Bright orientall Pearles in stead of teeth:</br>All which, embalmd the Heavens with their breath.</br>From thence sweete word and pleasing smiles did come,</br>All made to charme, and make beholders dome:</br>and which hard Rockes that stand in Seas aloft,</br>Could by their mighty power, of hard make soft.</br>Round was her Chin, with in whose dimples lay</br>Enchaunting spels, tho seeming faire and gay.</br>Her Neck a stay, this little worlde to 'pholde,</br>Of Ivorie was, or Alabaster mould,</br>Plast on two hils in whitnes that did passe</br>Her snow-white Breasts that was Agenous lasse:</br>Between which hils, Love often times did lurke,</br>When cruell stratagems he meant to worke.</br>Her little but long fingered Hand, more white</br>Then whitest Lillies that the Spring doth dight:</br>Her small Feete such as some say Tehtis has:</br>With which she nimbly could trip ore the Lawns,</br>And chace swift Row-bucks, and young wanton Fawns.

But for those parts the which her Garments hid,</br>What should we say?  Surely dame Nature did</br>Keepe those things secret, least they should excell</br>All she had made made in heaven, in earth, in hell.</br>But O!  what boots it to have thinges surpasse,</br>Since fairest thinges do fade like Sommers grasse:</br>Alas nought in this worlde doth firmely stay,</br>But turneth still like Billowes of the Sea:</br>Which neare do cease to roule with great rore,</br>Their rushing beat and breake against the shore.

And thou the cause of this unstablenesse,</br>That dost delight in nought but ficklenesse;</br>Whose customes never to abide in one,</br>But useth headlong dayly throw us downe,</br>When we are rays'd by thy benignitie,</br>Unto the top of all felicitie.

While thus with their faire Nimphs this lovely Queene</br>Was in this pleasant Meade, by them was seene</br>A Sheapheard, in the pride of all his dayes:</br>Who whilst his tender Flocke on salts did grase,</br>Sate sencelesse, like an Image made of stone</br>Long while, at last fetching a deepe sad grone</br>Of inward griefe, the trewest signe of all;</br>They foorth his eyen perceived salt tears to fall:</br>So after great Joves hidious thunders past,</br>A cloude of raine, the heavens doth overcast:</br>And when his teares were spent, with heavie cheare,</br>Sang to his Pipe this Song; which they did heare:</br>And hearing, could not choose but simpathise</br>His heavie griefe with water in their eyes.

O whither (quoth he) whither shall I flie,</br>To purchase ende unto my miserie?</br>Within what Rocke, or to what desart place,</br>That never is enricht by Phoebus face?</br>Shall I unfold in great and greevous paine,</br>Which makes me wretcheder then any Swaine?</br>If there be any place where dayly cries</br>The Night-rav'n and the Owle, that by night flies,</br>Whereto no living wight doth ere resort:</br>From whence foule Winter never doth depart,</br>And where the Spring her verdure will not sowe,</br>A place of deadly horror and foule woe,</br>Where ougly sorrow dayly may present,</br>Her selfe before mine eyes me to torment:</br>That will I choose as best befitting mee,</br>In this distresse and great extremitie.

And you my little flocke, the small remaine</br>Of a farre greater, which once more my payne</br>Might with most neighbour flockes have made compare</br>For number or for wooll, both fine and faire:</br>Then when for change of pasture sillie I,</br>In th' Aprill of mine age left Germanie;</br>Where I mongst Stadian bowers had nigh been slaine,</br>Cause I my Princesse honour did maintaine:</br>Then is the precious apple of mine eie:</br>And hoping for I wat not what to gaine,</br>To Englands pleasant soyle brought you againe.</br>Goe wander, goe; and take your libertie,</br>Grasing where is best pasture, while that I</br>Bewaile m' Icarian flight in mounting pride,</br>Plumed with waxe-forg'd-wings, which thought to ride</br>Above the cloudy welkin of the ayre,</br>To view the order their Latonas heire;</br>Holdeth in guiding of that glorious light,</br>That is the nourish of each living wight;</br>But was deceaved for comming neare the Sunne:</br>My winges did melt, and I did tumble downe.

O had I kept along the humble gill,</br>When first I did attempt to climbe the hill.</br>Or had I bounded mine ambitious minde,</br>Which carelesse thought to builde above the winde,</br>Sprung from remembraunce of those deedes were done</br>By my great Graundsirs, long-since dead and gone:</br>And a desire to register my' name,</br>Mought them within the sacred booke of fame:</br>Then might I now as I have done before,</br>Pasture you still along this pleasant shore.

Or had not rather greete Chrusophilus,</br>Whose greedy humor passing covetous,</br>Thought all that went beside himselfe quite lost:</br>Mee too much wronged, and mee too much crost;</br>Whose soule with many filthy crimes made blacke,</br>Now fleetes about Avernus fearefull lake:</br>Then might I now as I have done before,</br>Pasture you still along this pleasant shore.

For which, you Lordes of the infernall Bower,</br>Who ore deceased soules have mighty power,</br>T' inflict, or to remit their punishment:</br>O doe you all at my request assent,</br>Ixion from his wheele awhile to take;</br>And false Chrusophilus fast there to make.</br>Or if great Junos wrath be not yet done,</br>Let Sisiphus t'hen leave his rowling stone.</br>Or pull from Cawcasus Prometheus,</br>And let the Vultures teare Chrusophilus.</br>Or if that may not be, Jove angrie yet,</br>O then drag Tantalus foorth of his pit.</br>And let Chrusophilus up to the chin,</br>Still, but in vaine, wade up an' downe therein.</br>Let him at that faire seeming fruite, oft snatch;</br>Which thereby hanges, but never any catch.</br>A torment well beefitting such a wight,</br>Who living ore his owne,  had never might;</br>And let his late made gentle ofspring, which</br>Are with stolne Plumes of others pride made rich:</br>Dispoyld thereof like to their Grandsirs fare,</br>Who unto Ceres slavish servants weare.</br>And for assenting to my wished boone,</br>Sad Hecatombes by mee shall be done,</br>And monthly I will  offer a blacke Ramme,</br>As signe that I am thankfull for the same,</br>For had not he lately from mee bereft</br>Unjustly all my Sheepe, save these few left;</br>To stanch his never satisfied lust</br>Of Golde, earths drosse, that doth sonsume with rust;</br>Then might I now, as I have done before,</br>Pasture you still alongst this pleasant shore.</br>But since it cannot be as twas of late,</br>Since Fortune now hath given me the mate,</br>Dispoyld me quite of all my woonted mirth,</br>Clad me with woes, and throwne me to the earth:</br>And like a Tyrant triumphe over me,</br>That sore her prostrate on the ground doth lie;</br>Neare reckning whether it be just and sound,</br>To trouble him, lies govelling on the ground.

O you the remnant of a greater flocke,</br>Goe get you gone, while to some desart rocke</br>I make repaire, where for my bed shall be</br>The cold dry ground, whereon I still will lie;</br>For mounting mattens, mournings full of care:</br>For walkes, the wretched pathes of foule dispaire:</br>For meate, sad discontent:  for drinke, salt teares:</br>For nightly sleepes, nought else but slumbring feares;</br>Till those last dueties I doe pay to Nature,</br>Which I am bound too, beeing a mortall creature:</br>What time my soule freed from this earthly gaile,</br>Where now it tyred lyes, shall to thee vaile:</br>Of faire Elisium fly, where voyde of paine,</br>Mongst blessed soules in joy it shall remaine.</br>And thou sweete Pipe, the which wonts oft display</br>My wronges unto these Woodes, these Rockes, and Sea,</br>And moovest them at once to rew my lot,</br>When lyving men seemd sencelesse, and would not;</br>But helde hard hartes, the which I do repent,</br>More harder farre, then hardest Adamant.</br>From that rude race, degenerating nought,</br>Which was of hard Stone, by Deiecalion wrought.</br>Here hang thou (therewith on a Beechen tree</br>He hung his Pipe) for now no more for thee,</br>Nor for thy sugred melodie I care,</br>(Quoth he) which done like one drowned in dispaire:</br>Thence heavie he departed, passing nought,</br>What Fortune, or foule Envie could alot.

On whom, whilst ISIS lookt, perceive she might</br>The Sea to swell, which did her much affright:</br>For she discerned on their toppes to ride</br>Great Neptune, poasting to the shore with speede.</br>Whose comming so amas'd the fearefull Thams,</br>(Who knew full well that he those scorching flames,</br>With her faire eyes within his breast had wrought,</br>Would seeke to quench by force, if he her caught)</br>As in a shadie Wood the hydeous stroke</br>Of ratling Thunder on the sodaine broke,</br>Doth scare the small Birdes, pearched on the spray:</br>And like how Fowle that by a River play,</br>Spying a Falcon towring in the skie,</br>Straight leave their sport, and for their safetie flie,</br>Withouten order crying here and there:</br>So ISIS and her Nimphes, being in feare</br>Of hated Neptune, from thence straight gan fly,</br>Shreeking and crying very pitteously.

Aye me, What is this world but vanitie?</br>Subject to change; full of unconstancie:</br>Now is the Welkin glorious to the eie,</br>Clad in a Mantle of an asurd die.</br>And Phoebus now his faire light doth display,</br>When by and by a blacke Cloud foorth the Sea</br>Doth rise and darke the heavens were Joviall,</br>Troubling both ayre and earth with waters fall.

Aye, now I see that mourning followes mirth,</br>That sorrow driveth pleasure from the earth;</br>That happinesse doth not long time remaine,</br>But ere it is at full begi'nes to waine:</br>That all in vaine man strives to keepe his state,</br>When dangerous stormes labour it to abate:</br>That vainely men doe boast of Fortunes favours,</br>Since like a weather-cocke shee alwayes wavers,</br>Threatning them most, and bringing soonest under</br>Those, at whose fortunes most the world did wonder.

And strange, what ere within this world is done,</br>Ordayned was before this world begun:</br>so that great JOVE, who moderateth Heav'n</br>As soveraigne, and commaunds ore Gods and men:</br>At whose becke, earth and ayre, and all else move,</br>Will not one enterprise the Fates to prove:</br>Whome neither prayers, nor ought else can resist,</br>Cause still th' are fixt, and still in one persist.
